summaries.body: No matter how you work Carly Fiorina's numbers, she is facing a tough climb to get into the next Republican debate.
Instagram, the square-photo sharing app, announced that it would allow users the option to display their images and videos in landscape and portrait orientations.

display_asset.caption: Natural American Spirit was one of three cigarette brands warned about its marketing practices.

summaries.body: The F.D.A. issued warnings to Natural American Spirit, Winston and Nat Sherman cigarettes, saying the brands could not be marketed as “additive-free” or “natural.”
The five nominees for the Video of the Year at the V.M.A.’s all departed from their public images. Above, Beyoncé in her nominated video, “7/11.”

display_asset.caption: The School District of Philadelphia, which has succeeded in making school lunches more nutritious, tested fruit smoothies on students this month. The drink will be added to the menu in October.

summaries.body: New federal data showed that the humble school lunch has become healthier, improving substantially since higher government standards went into effect in 2012.
An English hacker who tapped into U.S. military networks has been killed in Syria, according to officials. Junaid Hussain, 21, was also a leading ISIS online recruiter.

posts.footer: The New York Times, and @TheAPJournalist on Twitter

summaries.body: The New York Daily News was criticized for publishing images from a deadly shooting in Virginia on its front page. A Twitter user circulated a blacked-out version.
Usain Bolt maintained his perch at the top of the world of sprinting for another year, but then he was knocked over by a cameraman riding a Segway.

display_asset.credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

summaries.body: In a special report, Consumer Reports asks, How safe is your ground beef? All samples in an analysis of U.S. ground beef were found to be contaminated with fecal matter.

posts.footer: The Courier-Journal (Louisville, Ky.) | The New York Times

summaries.body: Kim Davis, a Kentucky county clerk, could take her bid to stay an injunction ordering her to give marriage licenses to gay couples to the Supreme Court as early as Thursday.
Los Angeles used 21 percent less water in July 2015 than in July 2014, easily beating state targets imposed during California's drought and avoiding fees and penalties.
The start date for 24-hour weekend Tube service on some lines in London will be delayed to allow more time for talks with unions, which have already staged two strikes.
An Islamic State suicide bomber killed two army generals as they led forces against militant positions in Anbar Province, Iraq, west of Baghdad, military officials said.

display_asset.credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

summaries.body: Nicola Sturgeon, head of the Scottish National Party, wants the BBC to adopt a new structure with governance boards for England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
A driver on Long Island was charged with tampering after he used a pole to redirect several red-light cameras toward the sky and then posted a video of his exploits online.

display_asset.caption: StarKist was accused of underfilling some of its cans of tuna.

summaries.body: You may have $50 worth of free tuna waiting for you after StarKist settled a class-action lawsuit.
The U.S. will support a Sri Lankan plan to conduct an internal investigation into possible war crimes, a reversal from its earlier insistence on an international inquiry.

display_asset.caption: A smaller of two panda cubs born to Giant Panda Mei Xiang August 22 is fed from a bottle at the Smithsonian's National Zoo in Washington, in this picture taken August 24, 2015.

summaries.body: The smaller of twin giant panda cubs, born at the National Zoo in Washington on Saturday, died despite round-the-clock efforts to help the mother manage the two babies.
Iran said the American authorities are holding 19 Iranians on what it described as unfounded charges. The United States has been pressing Iran to release three Americans.
Marcy Borders, who became known as the “dust lady” from a defining photograph of her covered in ash and grime on Sept. 11, 2001, has died. She was 42.

display_asset.caption: President Joachim Gauck and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany visited a former government building in Berlin that is being used to house refugees.
display_asset.title: German Leaders Visit Refugee Shelter

summaries.body: President Joachim Gauck of Germany, above, and Chancellor Angela Merkel visted a refugee center, denouncing antimigrant violence and insisting, "Germany will help where help is needed."

display_asset.caption: Whether back-to-school means college or high school, apps can help a student stay organized and productive.
display_asset.credit: Produced by By KIT EATON and DALLAS JENSEN
display_asset.title: App Smart | Start School Right

summaries.body: It's back to school time. There's an app for that. These help students stay productive and organized -- though they can't guarantee good grades.
Amy Schumer, above, and the actress Jennifer Lawrence are co-writing a comedy about two sisters, and are planning to star in the film.
Two Kenyan runners, 21-year-old Koki Manunga and 29-year-old Joyce Zakary, above, were suspended after failing drug tests at the world championships in Beijing.
Britain's foreign-born population is set to top eight million for the first time in official figures to be published this week, according to Oxford University.
Flight operations at Dublin Airport have resumed after they were suspended this morning because of a fire in a hangar, forcing staff members to evacuate.
Jeremy Corbyn, the favorite to lead the Labour Party in Britain, said women-only train cars could be introduced to help guard against harassment at night.
The F.B.I. has started a civil rights inquiry at a jail in Kansas City, Mo., officials said. The local authorities have acknowledged cases of “possible use of excessive force.”
Water availability in Syria has been halved since its conflict began nearly four and a half years ago, disrupting supplies for millions, the United Nations said Tuesday.
The Red Cross said it was temporarily suspending its operations in Yemen’s southern port city of Aden after gunmen stormed the group's offices.
